蝴蝶照明后：单频闪设置即可拍摄令人惊叹的肖像！首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是克里斯蒂娜·N·迪克森。

本文于 2024 年 3 月更新，由 Christina N Dickson 和 Jaymes Dempsey 贡献。

如果您想拍摄精致的专业级人像照片，那么掌握一些基本的照明模式是值得的。现在，不同的图案可以产生截然不同的效果——例如，循环照明看起来相当中性，而分光照明则更加强烈——对于需要戏剧性、魅力型图像的照片拍摄，蝴蝶照明是很难击败的。

蝴蝶照明图案不仅看起来令人惊叹，而且在工作室中实现也非常容易。您可以使用单个灯光获得良好的效果（并且从那里，您可以随时添加不同的修饰符、反射器和补光灯以获得一系列炫酷的外观）。底线：如果您是工作室灯光初学者，蝴蝶图案是一个很好的起点。即使您是一位经验丰富的肖像摄影师，从长远来看，掌握蝴蝶技术也会带来回报。

在本文中，我将分享您需要了解的有关美丽蝴蝶照明设置的所有信息，包括：

  • 什么时候应该（和不应该）使用蝴蝶照明
  • 我推荐的蝴蝶灯光设备
  • 创建简单蝴蝶设置的分步方法
  • 修改设置以获得更好结果的高级方法

因此，如果您准备好开始使用这种华丽的照明技术，那么让我们开始吧！

什么是蝴蝶照明？

蝴蝶布光又称魅力布光、派拉蒙布光，是人像摄影的基本布光模式。它会在受试者的鼻子下产生典型的蝴蝶形阴影，因此得名蝴蝶。

如果您看上面的示例，您还会看到拍摄对象的嘴唇、下巴和颧骨下方有强烈的阴影。这是蝴蝶照明的标准：效果非常引人注目，而且光线很好地塑造了拍摄对象的脸部，营造出三维感。

请注意，蝴蝶照明与环形照明（鼻子阴影落在拍摄对象的脸颊上）和伦勃朗照明（阴影在一只眼睛下方形成三角形）不同。蝴蝶照明是直接照明的一种形式；光源直接来自拍摄对象的前方，营造出强大、戏剧性的外观。

什么时候应该使用蝴蝶照明？

如果处理得当，蝴蝶图案看起来会令人惊叹，但重要的是要认识到，这种戏剧性、强烈的效果并不适合所有肖像场景。

如果您要拍摄时尚肖像或魅力照片，那么蝴蝶照明将非常适合您。您将能够为模特提供时尚杂志中经常出现的雕刻照明效果。我还认为该图案适用于正式的肖像拍摄，但您需要确保光线相对柔和（通过添加强漫射器），以防止阴影太重和太明显。

然而，由于蝴蝶光往往会让脸部看起来更瘦、更锐利，而且还会增加一丝强度和戏剧性，所以我建议在拍摄需要更自然、朴素外观的照片时避免使用它。例如，在进行儿童课程、家庭课程和参与课程时，我通常不会尝试蝴蝶技巧。相反，我会寻找其他肖像照明模式，使拍摄对象看起来不错，而又不会引起人们的注意（例如上面提到的循环照明）。

如何进行蝴蝶照明：三步过程

幸运的是，蝴蝶照明不仅在正确的场景下看起来令人惊叹，而且也很容易实现。你需要某种灯；我建议使用热靴闪光灯或影室闪光灯，不过您也可以使用连续灯。如果你没有人造灯，窗户灯是另一种选择——它不太容易控制，但只要阳光不直接照射进来，照明就会非常柔和。

假设您使用人造光，您将需要一个坚固的灯架。我还鼓励您手头上有一个反光镜，尽管这不是绝对必要的。

第 1 步：将光线直接放置在拍摄对象的正前方

蝴蝶照明首先将光线直接指向拍摄对象（因此光束射向拍摄对象的鼻子）。

将灯光放在灯架上，并确保它以直线指向拍摄对象的中心。然后将其举到拍摄对象上方，保持其朝向拍摄对象脸部倾斜，直到达到 45 度角（或左右角度）。

您可以自由调整高度，但您需要足够的空间将相机放置在灯光下，并且您还需要足够高的灯光才能创造出美丽的蝴蝶阴影。 （光线越高，阴影越长 - 因此，如果您正在寻找更强烈、更戏剧化的效果，请将光线调得更高！）

进行测试拍摄。你不需要关注整体曝光度；只要确保你有正确的阴影形状即可。然后继续下一步：

第二步：添加反光板

此时，您应该具有基本的蝴蝶外观（简单，对吧？），但通常稍微降低拍摄对象鼻子、下巴、眼睛和脸部下方阴影的强度是值得的。

因此，我建议在拍摄对象的下巴下方添加一个反光板。反光板距离拍摄对象越近，蝴蝶阴影就会越柔和 - 因此，请通过取景器观察并进行一些测试拍摄，直到获得所需的外观。

如果您想要更多控制，可以使用第二盏灯而不是反射器。确保光线比主光弱几档（毕竟，您不想完全抵消阴影，或者更糟糕的是，将其向上发送！）。

专业提示：检查拍摄对象的眼睛是否有一两个漂亮的聚光灯。如果主光或反射器/补光灯位置太高或太低，您可能会失去聚光灯（这会给您的肖像带来生机感）。

另外，请记住：您需要将相机安装在上部灯和下部反射器之间。在继续进行设置之前，请确保您可以在两个项目之间舒适地进行拍摄。

第 3 步：拨入相机设置

最后，您需要仔细曝光拍摄。我建议将相机设置为手动模式，然后提前调整快门速度、 ISO和光圈。

假设您使用闪光灯，快门速度应由相机的最大闪光同步速度决定（通常约为 1/160 秒或 1/200 秒）。根据您想要实现的景深选择光圈（对于全黑背景，f/8 区域的光圈应该没问题 - 它可以使拍摄对象从鼻尖到鼻尖保持清晰）他们的后脑勺）。

然后拨入相机的基本 ISO 值（通常为 ISO 100，但在某些相机上，可能略有不同！）。 ISO 越低，您就越不用担心文件中出现令人不快的噪声斑点。

此时，您的图像可能曝光度很差，但这是可以预料的。您需要依靠闪光灯功率来调整图像亮度；考虑使用手持式测光表来准确测量适当的曝光变量。

不要害怕进行多次测试，尤其是刚开始时。网络共享可以提供很大的帮助，我总是喜欢向初学者推荐它，尤其是那些使用闪光灯而不是连续灯的人；它可以让您在大型计算机显示器上查看图像，这样您就可以准确地知道您得到了什么以及需要调整什么。 （当然，您可以在相机的液晶显示屏上查看文件，但根据我的经验，这不足以评估微妙的灯光效果；很容易错过关键细节，例如太暗的阴影或缺少聚光灯。）

修改蝴蝶照明设置以获得最佳效果

虽然基本的蝴蝶照明模式非常棒，并且它绝对可以让您拍摄出大量专业级的照片，但修改和增强您的设置以获得独特的出色效果总是好的。

以下是一些有关更高级蝴蝶照明的提示：

1.添加光照修改器

您可以使用裸闪光灯或热靴闪光灯进行蝴蝶照明，但如果您想创造更漂亮的效果，我建议您在光源中添加修饰符。裸露光源非常小，小光会产生更刺眼、边缘硬朗的阴影，使拍摄对象变得扁平。这就是为什么几乎所有肖像摄影师（包括我自己）都使用修饰器，修饰器位于光源和拍摄对象之间以柔化阴影。

美容盘是一个很好的起点，因为它们可以柔化光线，同时保持方向性，打造迷人的外观。如果您追求更加柔和、飘逸的外观，请考虑使用柔光箱而不是美容盘。柔光箱越大，光线就越柔和（因此，如果您喜欢柔和的光线，请尝试使用 6 英尺以上的八角柔光箱）！

修饰器可能会有点贵，但有一些很棒的预算品牌（如 Neewer）提供质量合理的柔光箱、美容盘等，价格约为 40-100 美元。只需确保您购买的调节器与您的灯光相匹配 - 不同的灯光有不同的安装座，如果您不小心，您最终会得到一个不合适的柔光箱！

（顺便说一句：一旦你完成了足够多的肖像拍摄，并且一旦你掌握了足够的照明模式，你的房子/工作室周围可能会拥有大量的修改器。是的，我是根据经验说的这里！）

2. 将光线移近或远离拍摄对象

如果您的灯光看起来不像您想要的那么硬或软，您可能会倾向于关注您正在使用的修改器。光太难？在上面放一个大柔光箱。光线太柔和？而是添加一个美容盘。

但是，虽然修改器是处理光质量问题的有用方法，但您也可以通过另一种方式创建更硬和更软的照明效果：

通过将光线移近或远离拍摄对象。

一旦你建立了基本的蝴蝶照明模式，如果你将灯光移得更近，阴影就会柔化。如果你将光线移得更远，阴影就会变得更硬、对比度更高。

自己测试一下这可能是一个巧妙的小练习——只需在闪光灯上弹出修改器，找到一个愿意的拍摄对象，设置蝴蝶图案，然后在将光源移近和移远时拍摄一系列图像。

请记住，您不能只是移动灯光并希望得到最好的结果；每次灯光调整时，您都需要更改镜头的其他元素 - 灯光的功率、灯光的角度 - 以确保获得一致的结果。

3.添加背景

如果您追求超专业的外观，我建议您在镜头中添加背景 - 独立于模特进行照明的背景。

您可以手绘背景，可以使用白纸，可以找到自然令人惊叹的背景，或者您可以在线购买大型织物和/或纸张背景。

另一种选择是使用一张灰纸，然后使用 Photoshop 添加不同的背景文件。

一般来说，背景照明最好独立于主要拍摄对象。因此，首先要为拍摄对象创建一个低调的图像——背景完全变成黑色。然后在背景上放置一盏具有足够功率的灯光，在拍摄对象后面形成一个艺术环。

（您可能希望将灯光直接放在拍摄对象后面，以便均匀地照亮背景；或者，您可以使用位于框外两侧的两个灯光。）

4.添加边缘光

最好的肖像往往包含主题和背景之间的分离。换句话说，您可以清楚地看到主体在哪里结束，背景在哪里开始。

这就是边缘照明的用武之地：它照亮拍摄对象的边缘，以便美丽的背景和庄严的拍摄对象之间有明显的区别。

请注意，边缘光只会添加到您的蝴蝶设置中。您不需要对主要图案进行任何调整，我建议您在尝试边缘光之前实现所有必要的蝴蝶元素。

将边缘光放置在拍摄对象的后面并远离侧面，这样它就能从背面塑造您的拍摄对象。从技术上讲，您可以在另一侧第二次执行此操作，但通常一个边缘光就足够了。

然后进行一些测试拍摄，尝试不同的边缘光曝光值和位置。理想情况下，您将在拍摄对象的背面获得非常轻微的边缘。

使用蝴蝶照明拍摄一些令人惊叹的肖像！

蝴蝶照明是一种令人惊叹的肖像图案 - 而且非常容易实现。

因此，请按照本文中的说明进行操作。尝试不同的照明修饰符和位置。并玩得开心！

激发你灵感的 10 个春季摄影创意帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是西蒙·邦德。

本文由 Simon Bond 和 Jaymes Dempsey 于 2024 年 3 月更新。

春天对于几乎所有类型的摄影来说都是一个美好的时光。有很多令人惊叹的主题和机会：户外肖像、盛开的花朵和发芽的树木的微距照片、春天的风景和小动物等等。

也就是说，如果您是初学者，或者在漫长的冬天后感觉有点缺乏灵感，您可能很难想出那种让您兴奋地带着相机出门的春季摄影创意。这就是本文派上用场的地方！

从我记事起，我就一直对在春天拍照感到兴奋——我经常在冬天梦想着春天的拍摄机会——下面，我分享了 10 个易于遵循的春季摄影乐趣创意。

顺便说一句，您无需长途跋涉即可拍摄美丽的春天照片。 （其中许多想法都可以在您的后院或当地的公园中解决！）您也不需要复杂的装备；只需简单地操作即可。我为每个新想法提供了装备建议，但你只需要一台便宜的相机（甚至智能手机）和一些良好的光线就可以拍摄大部分春天的照片。

准备好享受春天的美景了吗？那么让我们开始吧！

1. 注重细节

无论您拍摄什么，捕捉细节始终是一个好主意 - 在创作春季构图时尤其如此。

如果您喜欢拍摄自然风光，您可以拿出微距镜头，拍摄一些令人惊叹的风铃草、水仙花或樱花的照片。

（我非常喜欢拍摄春天的花朵，从三月底/四月初的番红花开始，然后是四月底和五月的郁金香！虽然我通常喜欢使用微距镜头进行此类摄影，但也可以使用标准 50 毫米镜头或智能手机相机拍摄较大花朵（如郁金香）的精彩特写镜头。如果您能找到一片花田，您可以随时享受广角构图带来的乐趣，展示令人惊叹的色彩和图案……）

如果自然摄影不适合您，请不要担心！春天是外出游玩的好时机，所以如果您喜欢在城市或节日拍摄，您仍然可以寻找一些精美的细节照片。

特别是，旨在拍摄：

  • 散景： 散景和细节照片很好地结合在一起，而且在近距离拍摄时很容易产生美丽的散景。只需尽可能扩大镜头光圈，将镜头推至最大放大倍率，然后调整构图以将颜色和/或灯光包含在背景中即可。您可以使用任何镜头创建漂亮的散景效果，但使用微距镜头或具有较大最大光圈的定焦镜头效果最佳。而且镜头的焦距越长，就越容易使散景看起来平滑。
  • 图案：大自然充满了漂亮的图案，因此请充分利用它。花朵可以重复出现，从而拍摄出非常漂亮的微距照片。或者您可以拍摄地面上的花瓣图案（花瓣落下后）。春节期间，农产品往往被摆成图案，非常适合拍照。
  • 背景：摄影师倾向于关注主要主题，但您是否知道有趣的背景是精彩照片的重要组成部分？它们也不难创建。只需调整您的构图，直到获得干净、美丽的背景效果 - 使用大光圈会有所帮助！ –然后迅速离开。如果您不确定如何开始，请尝试在晴朗的日子里向天空拍摄以获得漂亮的蓝色背景，或者向下瞄准草地以获得绿色背景。
  • 灯光：最好的摄影师知道如何使用光线来产生各种有趣的效果，你也可以这样做！事实上，一个很棒的春季摄影理念是选择一个主题，然后拍摄十张仅在光线方面有所不同的图像。例如，如果您正在拍摄一朵花，您可以捕捉透过花瓣的光线、显着照亮花茎的侧光、产生有趣的耀斑效果的背光等等。

2.在春季摄影中探索更广阔的场景

当拍摄春天的美景（例如花朵和植物）时，您可能会想靠近并停留在那里。

虽然这肯定会给你带来一些令人惊叹的照片，但你也可以通过切换到广角镜头并从远处拍摄场景来捕捉美丽的照片。毕竟，花坛、开花的树木和撒满花瓣的小路可以拍出一些美丽的风景照片！

顺便说一句，如果您想捕捉一些美丽的春天构图 - 特别是如果您想包括花朵 - 这里有一些建议：

  • 查看天气预报：这里我说的是天气预报和花期预报。天气预报可以确保您在光线好的时候进行拍摄，而开花预报可以让您在花期进行拍摄。
  • 构图为王：与所有风景摄影一样，良好的构图将为您带来最佳效果。旨在通过对称、 三分法则和赔率法则等构图技术来平衡您的春季照片。还可以将引导线融入到照片中，以增添一点额外的活力。
  • 添加额外的背景信息：还记得我如何鼓励您使用广角镜头吗？尽可能广泛并包含一些背景信息。例如，在当地建筑旁拍摄一棵樱桃树，或者拍摄一个走过花瓣地的人。

3.尝试自由镜头

自由镜头是一种创造性的技术，可以让您调整镜头的焦平面，而无需花费数千美元购买移轴玻璃。您可以生成各种充满令人惊叹的模糊效果的原始结果。

它的工作原理如下：

首先，确保您的相机已关闭。小心地将镜头从相机上拆下，然后将其放置在镜头座的正前方。 （您可以左手握住镜头，右手握住相机。）

重新打开相机，然后通过取景器查看。慢慢地前后倾斜镜头，观察焦点所在的场景区域如何根据镜头的位置而变化。

当您准备好拍照时，只需按下快门按钮即可！

自由拍摄需要大量的实验，你会得到很多失败的照片 - 但成功会让你觉得一切都是值得的。可以尝试的几种方法：

  • 将镜头拉近或远离镜头座以获得不同级别的放大倍率
  • 更改焦距（尽管 50mm 是一个很好的起点）
  • 故意在相机和镜头之间留出一些空间，以防止漏光

请注意，您可以使用自由镜头来捕捉许多不同主题的创意镜头。许多自由镜头专注于花卉和植物 - 正如我上面提到的，这始终是一个很好的春季照片主题 - 但您也可以拍摄有趣的肖像、风景等！

需要注意的是：自由镜头会将相机的传感器暴露于外界，并且会增加相机或镜头掉落的可能性。如果可能的话，我建议使用备用相机和便宜的镜头！ （我通常使用旧的数码单反相机和我的佳能 50mm f/1.8 定焦镜头进行自由镜头，尽管在我使用这些技术的所有时间里，我从未真正损坏过我的设备；从中获取你想要的！）

4.拍摄一些户外人像

春天是人像摄影的好时节。您可以找到一些令人惊叹的自然背景，此外您还可以将有趣的花卉主题融入您的春季照片中。

以下是一些简单的春季摄影创意：

  • 将主题与树木结合起来：客户喜欢包含美丽自然背景的肖像。将拍摄对象放在树木或花朵前面，然后使用大光圈模糊背景。树木的线条可以增加照片的深度，而花朵则可以创造出令人惊叹的背景颜色斑点。为了获得良好的触感，请让你的模特拿着一两朵花。
  • 进行春季抓拍摄影：随着天气变暖，人们开始外出享受公园生活，您将有很多机会拍摄享受春天的人们。您可以捕捉人们走过鲜花盛开的田野、人们徒步穿越森林、人们在草地上享受野餐等等。
  • 自拍：这可能不是最原始的春季照片创意，但每个人都需要一张新的春季个人资料照片。因此，下次有机会时，拍一张自拍照（并确保在画面中加入一两朵花！）。

5. 进行实验

春天摄影是一个广泛的主题，但如果你花点时间浏览 Instagram，你会发现大多数春天照片通常都是一样的。

想要改变一下现状吗？突破这些实验技术，例如有意的相机移动、图像合成等等。以下是我最喜欢的一些在春天发挥创意的方法：

  • 尝试小径：春天的树叶经常长在路边。晚上散步，带上三脚架，拍一些车灯轨迹照片。一定要包括一些春天的花朵作为背景！
  • 拍摄折射照片：如果您还没有尝试过水晶球摄影，那么您就错过了！水晶球价格便宜，而且它们可以产生惊人的效果（见下面的镜头！）。
  • 故意拍摄运动模糊：谁说模糊一定是不好的？在有风的日子外出，将相机放在三脚架上，并使用较慢的快门速度。如果您可以在移动过程中捕捉植物和花卉，您将创造出一些美丽的抽象效果！

6.不要忘记春节

我上面分享的大部分想法都涉及花卉和植物，但在春节和宗教节日也有很多精彩的照片可供拍摄。

带上你的相机和几个镜头（我推荐快速定焦镜头和广角变焦镜头）。享受从远处拍摄主体的乐趣（以便捕捉整个活动的氛围）。然后近距离拍摄一些坦率的街拍。

尝试用您的照片讲述一个故事。活动现场发生了什么？这是关于什么的？人们如何参与？

带着一部讲述节日故事的迷你连续剧离开！

7.捕捉剪影

春天的夜晚更长，这意味着您有更多的时间在良好的光线下拍摄（即使您在一周内工作很长时间！）。那么为什么不拍一张有趣的剪影照片来庆祝额外的春天阳光呢？

找到一个愿意的拍摄对象，然后选择一个有足够开放空间的地点。您需要确保您的构图能够使您的拍摄对象与天空隔绝；拥有自然的海拔点（例如巨石）会有很大的帮助。

等到傍晚时——太阳在天空中很低的时候——然后调整好自己的位置，让太阳从拍摄对象的后面射过来。您不需要将太阳保持在画面中，但要确保拍摄对象后面的区域非常明亮。

接下来，将镜头对准天空最亮的部分，然后用它来设置曝光。目标是在拍摄对象严重曝光不足的情况下对天空进行适当曝光。在优化曝光时拍摄几张测试照片会很有帮助（您始终可以使用曝光补偿来使文件变亮或变暗，或者可以切换到手动模式并调整快门速度）。

最后，精心构图。正如我上面提到的，您需要一个整洁的背景，这通常很容易通过降低到地面或引导您的拍摄对象站在某个东西上（例如岩石或矮墙）来实现。

并采取你的射击！如果一切顺利，您最终会得到一个令人惊叹的结果，尽管我鼓励您稍后进行一些后期处理，以显示天空的颜色并确保您的拍摄对象足够暗。

8.寻找野生动物

春天充满生机，其中包括候鸟、小哺乳动物等等！在当地的公园或自然保护区花一些时间，您一定会发现一两只动物可以拍照。即使您一般不喜欢野生动物摄影，春天也是开始拍摄的好时机。看看是否能找到一个动物相对温顺的区域，例如有很多经常步行的公园。

为了获得最佳效果，您需要使用长焦镜头。 55-200 毫米套件镜头通常足够长，适合大型、驯服的野生动物（例如鹅），但如果您想捕捉小型鸣禽和远处的哺乳动物，则 300 毫米、400 毫米及以上的镜头是最佳选择。

也就是说，您可以通过扩大范围并创造更多包括动物和周围栖息地的环境构图来拍摄精彩的照片，因此不要觉得长焦镜头是绝对必要的。

（如果你想拍摄鸟类并且不介意做一些额外的工作，你可以随时在后院设置喂食器和临时百叶窗。花一些时间坐在百叶窗里，让镜头伸出来，很快，你就会看到鸟儿摆出各种有趣的姿势！几年前我尝试过这样做，在我的百叶窗（实际上只是一个帐篷）里待了几个小时后，我拍到了数百张红雀的特写照片、山雀、雀等。）

野生动物摄影的一个快速提示：耐心往往会得到回报。不要简单地走过一个主题，拍几张照片，然后继续你的方式；相反，如果有时间，请将镜头对准动物，直到它摆出有趣的姿势。这可能很困难，特别是因为永远无法保证一定会发生某些事情，但当你幸运时，结果往往是惊人的。

9.在雨中拍摄街景

春天以多雨天而闻名，但我鼓励您不要呆在室内，而是利用温暖的气温，带着相机前往户外。去最近的城市或城镇，看看是否可以捕捉到一些喜怒无常、被大雨浸透的街景。

在这里，35 毫米或 50 毫米定焦镜头通常是最好的，但如果您只有标准套件镜头，也没关系。寻找有趣的时刻和人与人之间的互动，并确保仔细注意场景的整体框架。很容易忘记街头构图中的所有元素，但重要的是，即使世界看起来很混乱，也要让一切井井有条！

如果您愿意接受挑战，您甚至可以尝试在黄昏时出发。您需要一个最大光圈较宽的镜头，但如果您愿意投入工作，您可以拍摄结合雨伞、湿反射和散景的照片！

不过，我要补充一点，春天的夜晚可能会很冷，尤其是下雨的时候，所以不要忘记穿得体的衣服。

如果您在小毛毛雨以外的环境中拍摄，最好使用防雨罩进行保护。这些基本上只是小塑料袋，可以贴在您的设备周围，防止水损坏电子设备。经过多年在雨中拍摄后，我总是在相机包里携带一些专用的防雨罩，但如果您不想花额外的钱，您可以随时用垃圾袋和几根橡皮筋制作自己的防雨罩。 （顺便说一句，我曾经用两条橡皮筋和一个百吉饼套制作了一个防雨罩！它很好地保护了我的长焦镜头免受降水的影响，尽管我承认它看起来相当愚蠢......）

10.享受室内静物画的乐趣

在世界某些地区，春天——尤其是早春——看起来与冬天没有太大区别。如果您有这样的经历，请看看您是否可以通过拍摄以水果和/或花朵为特色的静物照片来在室内重现春天的感觉！

只需前往商店购买一些梨、苹果、樱桃或任何其他您认为有吸引力的物品即可。切花花束也可以看起来很棒，尤其是与彩色花瓶搭配时。

然后在地下室设立一个小型工作室区域，仔细注意用来展示主题的表面。 （我喜欢使用我从房地产拍卖中便宜买来的旧木桌，但你几乎可以使用任何东西：板条箱、长凳、木板、大理石板、砖块，甚至地板。）

您还需要仔细考虑这里的背景。朴素的墙壁很好，但您需要确保颜色不会与您的拍摄对象发生冲突。另一种选择是在你的设置后面悬挂一些深色的东西——我使用一块大的黑色桌布——并追求低调的外观，背景逐渐变成黑暗。

如果您拥有闪光灯或闪光灯，您可以尝试不同的照明设置，但如果您更喜欢使用自然光，也没关系！只需将您的静物设置放置在窗户旁边（某种形式的侧光通常是理想的选择，因为它会给您带来更加立体的效果）。

并确保你花大量时间调整你的构图元素。在静物摄影中，即使拍摄对象的位置发生轻微变化，也会极大地改变照片的感觉，因此您可以尝试越多不同的布置就越好！

春季摄影创意：最后的话

如果您所在的地区正值春天，我希望您至少会发现其中一些想法鼓舞人心。今年春天我肯定会出去走走——拍摄花朵、风景、户外活动等等。我希望能在那里看到你！

因此，借鉴一些春季摄影创意并享受乐趣吧！带上相机出发吧！拍摄一些春天的照片！享受温暖的天气！

如何在 Lightroom 中使用 HDR 合并：分步指南一文首先出现在Digital Photography School上。它的作者是安德鲁·S·吉布森。

HDR 技术是在照片的高光和阴影中保留大量细节的好方法，特别是在处理高对比度场景（例如日落风景）时。

但是，一旦您在现场捕获了多个括号内的文件，您就需要在后期处理中合并它们。

现在，有很多插件可以与 Lightroom 一起使用来创建高质量的 HDR 照片，但事实是 Lightroom 自己的 HDR 合并功能做得非常出色。通过 HDR Merge，您可以直接在 Lightroom 中创建 HDR 文件，并且无需支付任何插件或额外费用。

在本文中，我将解释为什么我推荐 Lightroom 的 HDR 合并功能来混合文件，并且我将分享获得出色的最终图像的分步过程（使用我自己的几张 HDR 风景照片作为示例） 。

让我们开始吧！

使用 Lightroom 内置 HDR 合并功能的优势

如果您与其他使用 HDR 技术的摄影师交谈，您可能会发现每个人都有不同的软件偏好。有些人使用 Photoshop，其他人则信赖 Luminar Neo 的 HDR Merge 扩展，还有一些人依赖 Photomatix Pro 等专用 HDR 程序。

虽然上述所有选项都可以完成工作，但使用 Lightroom 进行 HDR 转换有几个优点：

  1. 你省钱了。大多数 HDR 插件都不是免费的，如果您在工作流程中依赖不同的编辑器或专用 HDR 程序，则可能需要支付大量费用。但如果您已经订阅了 Lightroom，则内置 HDR 合并功能。
  2. Lightroom 的 HDR 合并可创建自然的 HDR 图像。并不是每个人都会认为这是一个优势，但 Lightroom 在避免花哨、过度饱和的 HDR 照片方面做得很好。
  3. 您不需要大量括号内的图像。根据我的经验，两个就足以获得良好的结果：一个在 -2 档曝光，另一个在 +2 档曝光。 （如果需要，您可以使用更多括号内的文件，如果您有一个对比鲜明的场景，这可能是一个好主意 - 但一般来说，两个应该可以很好地工作。）
  4. 最终的 HDR 图像保存为 DNG 文件。 DNG 文件不仅比 TIFF 文件小，而且您可以像处理任何其他 DNG 或 RAW 文件一样在 Lightroom 中处理它。主要区别在于“曝光”滑块从 -10 到 + 10 档运行，而不是正常的 -4 到 +4。当您使用阴影和高光滑块进行调整时（以及使用 Lightroom 的遮罩工具应用有针对性的调整时），文件中还有更多信息供 Lightroom 使用。
  5. 您可以手持拍摄括号内的序列，Lightroom 会自动对齐它们。 Lightroom 的自动对齐选项可让您处理多张不具有相同取景框的照片。话虽如此，我发现最好的结果确实来自使用三脚架安装的相机拍摄的包围照片！

如何在 Lightroom 中使用 HDR Merge 合并括号内的照片

使用 Lightroom 的内置 HDR 工具非常简单 - 因此，即使您不是经验丰富的照片编辑器，也不应该遇到任何问题！只需按照以下说明操作：

从图库模块中的网格视图开始，然后选择要合并的图像。或者，您可以在“冲印”模块胶片中选择图像。

右键单击所选图像，然后选择照片合并>;HDR 。 （您也可以在主菜单中选择“照片>;照片合并>;HDR” 。）

HDR 合并预览窗口应该打开，您将看到 Lightroom 的 HDR 图像预览。请注意，加载预览可能需要一些时间，特别是当您选择了很多图像进行合并时。

您可能会惊讶地发现没有太多需要调整的设置。这是经过深思熟虑的 - 目的是让 Lightroom 生成看起来自然的 HDR 图像，然后您可以在“修改照片”模块中对其进行处理以实现您想要的外观。但你确实有几个选择：

默认情况下，自动对齐和自动设置框将被选中，并且Deghost 数量将设置为None 。 （如果您更改设置，Lightroom 会记住您最后的输入，因此请务必确保在继续之前使用正确的设置！）

这些 HDR 合并设置有什么作用？

如果相机在曝光之间移动（这通常发生在手持时），自动对齐非常有用。如果选中此框，Lightroom 将排列不同的图像，使混合文件看起来自然。

自动设置与修改照片模块的基本面板中的自动设置执行类似的功能。

我发现 HDR 合并在勾选“自动对齐”和“自动设置”框时效果最佳（见下文）。还有更改去重影量的选项 - 此处的目标是防止因帧之间的主体移动而导致的任何伪影（例如线条或模糊）。如果您的场景完全静止，只需将设置保留为“无”即可；但是，如果镜头之间存在运动，例如一棵树在风中摇曳或一个人在风景中小跑，您可以将“消重影量”设置为“低”、 “中”或“高” 。

您无法在 HDR 合并预览窗口中放大至 100%，因此只有在进入“修改照片”模块并放大至 1:1 后，您可能才会意识到重影。如果您在该阶段发现重影，您可以随时返回并重新处理图像。您还可以勾选“显示重影叠加”框以显示 Lightroom 检测到重影的区域。

（你怎么知道哪个 Deghost 量是最好的？老实说，你只需要反复试验——每组图像都是不同的。）

调整完设置后，继续并单击底部的“合并”按钮。 Lightroom 会将合并的图像保存为 DNG 文件，并在文件名后附加后缀 -HDR。它还会将您带回您开始的模块。从那里，您可以在“修改照片”模块中正常编辑图像。

这是我的 HDR 合并的结果。我用了两张照片，中间间隔一站。这并不是很多包围，但那是一个阴天，我想要一张能够捕捉风景和天空细节的照片。在阳光明媚的日子里，光线的对比度较高，因此您通常需要使用间隔更远的包围图像。

您已经合并了图像 – 现在怎么办？

您的 HDR 文件应被视为处理的起点。这是一个新的 RAW 文件，您可以在“修改照片”模块中对其进行编辑以达到所需的效果。

就我而言，我认为合并的照片太亮，因此我在“修改照片”模块中将其变暗。我还做了一些色调调整并增加了清晰度。这是同一张图像，但在应用这些编辑之后：

下面的屏幕截图显示了 HDR 图像（右）和没有任何曝光补偿的同一张照片（左）之间的比较。如您所见，合并两次曝光使我能够捕捉到灰云中的细节。

注意：如果合并文件后，您认为图像具有太多 HDR 感觉，则可以使用基本面板滑块或局部调整来更改色调值。例如，您可以增加“阴影”或“黑色”设置来增加对比度，这样就不会出现过度 HDR 典型的“每个阴影中都有不自然的细节”效果。

这是另一个例子，这次是在阳光下拍摄的照片，其亮度范围要大得多。这两张照片分别是在+1和-1站拍摄的：

这是 Lightroom 在 HDR 合并过程后给出的结果：

这是在“开发”模块中编辑后的样子：

差异是微妙的；我只是将图像调暗一点，并将“高光”滑块移至零，以尽可能多地呈现云中的细节。

高对比度示例

到目前为止，我已经向您展示了 Lightroom 的 HDR Merge 如何处理包含中等色调范围的文件。但是，如果场景的色调范围很大，迫使您创建三个或更多包围图像怎么办？

下一个示例涉及三张照片，曝光总共有七档差异。您可能不需要在日常拍摄中使曝光差异如此之大，但尝试总是很有趣。

结果如下：

每个版本的照片中的水看起来都不同，因此我将 Deghost Amount 设置为High 。请注意，消重影区域（如下图红色所示）覆盖了所有的水——当我比较三张原始图像时，我可以看到 Lightroom 使用了序列中第一张照片中的水，避免了由将三张照片合并，每张照片中的水位不同。

找不到新的 HDR 文件？

如果您不确定在哪里可以找到新创建的 HDR 文件，请在网格视图中将“排序”设置为“文件名” ，它将出现在序列中第一张图像的旁边（但请确保您位于原始文件夹中，而不是在集合中）。

最后的笔记

最好对尚未在“修改照片”模块中编辑的文件执行 HDR 合并过程，因为 Lightroom 仅在最终文件中保留一些调整后的设置。

这些取自您的一张图像并应用于 HDR 文件。下面列出了它们（所有其他设置都恢复为默认值）：

  • 混色器面板

Lightroom 还需要访问原始照片文件。它无法仅通过智能预览创建 HDR 图像。

帖子拍摄 RAW+JPEG 是两全其美吗？首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是吉姆·哈梅尔。

多年来，摄影师们一直在争论是使用 RAW 还是 JPEG 进行拍摄。 （好吧，也许“辩论”这个词用得不对。通常，这是经验丰富的摄影师鼓励初学者开始以 RAW 格式拍摄并停止以 JPEG 格式拍摄的问题。）

毫无疑问，RAW 文件在技术上更为优越。它们具有很多优点：更大的动态范围、更多的色彩信息和可调节的白平衡，仅举三点。

然而，只有在对文件进行后处理时才能真正体会到这些好处。因此，对于不想编辑文件的摄影师来说，RAW 摄影的优点并不真正适用，并且某些 RAW 缺点（例如需要在共享或打印之前处理每个文件）似乎不值得它。

通常，这个 RAW 与 JPEG 问题是作为一个非此即彼的命题提出的。有人告诉您必须决定以 RAW或JPEG 进行拍摄，并考虑这两种文件格式的优缺点。

但如果您可以同时拥有这两种格式的优点，这难道不是一个可行的方法吗？您不想将 RAW 文件的编辑灵活性与 JPEG 的即时共享性结合起来吗？这可能吗？

事实上，确实如此！

查看菜单中相机的质量或图像质量设置。大多数相机允许您对RAW 和 JPEG 进行该设置。这称为 RAW+JPEG 拍摄，每次按下快门按钮时，相机都会捕获 RAW 文件和 JPEG 文件。使用RAW+JPEG，您不是两全其美吗？

让我们来看看。但首先，让我们回顾一下 RAW 文件与 JPEG 文件的优势。

JPEG

当您拍照时，您的相机实际上正在获取从图像传感器接收的数据并创建文件。在数字化的早期，一群专家聚集在一起，商定了一种每个人都可以使用的文件格式。它被称为“JPEG”，代表“联合摄影专家组”。

这个想法是每个人都可以使用相同的格式，因此很容易共享。你知道吗？效果很好。 JPEG 或多或少无处不在。如果您拿起相机并开始拍摄，您通常会创建 JPEG 文件。它几乎是每个专用相机的默认设置。由于互联网浏览器开发人员始终在其软件中内置 JPEG 支持，因此您在网上看到的几乎所有图片都采用这种格式。

但是当您的相机创建 JPEG 时，会发生一些事情。首先是相机对图片数据进行了压缩，因此文件大小更小。 JPEG 只会使用相机捕获的大约四分之一的数据，因此会丢弃大量数据。其中一些是颜色数据，这是通过减少可用颜色的数量来完成的（尽管 JPEG 中仍然有很多可用的颜色）。您会看到最大影响的是高光和阴影，其中可能会丢失一些细节。

此外，当创建 JPEG 时，您的相机会对图片进行一些处理。相机制造商知道您希望相机发出的照片看起来清晰且色彩丰富。因此，它们在渲染 JPEG 文件时添加了一些效果，例如清晰度、对比度和饱和度。好处是你的照片通常看起来更好一点，但缺点是你无法控制整个过程，有时你的相机的处理与你想要的不匹配。

这就引出了 RAW 文件。

RAW的优势

在大多数相机中，您可以进入菜单并将文件格式更改为“RAW”。不，实际上并不存在某种称为 RAW 的通用文件格式。相反，每台相机都有自己的方式来捆绑从图像传感器接收的数据，以创建自己的专有文件（尼康为 NEF，佳能为 CRW 或 CR2，富士为 RAF 等）。生成的文件称为“RAW”。

您可能已经注意到一个问题：由于 RAW 文件的格式不同，因此它们不容易共享。此外，RAW 文件很大，通常是 JPEG 文件大小的 3-4 倍。

那么为什么几乎每个人都推荐拍摄 RAW 格式呢？因为它们包含更多信息。还记得 JPEG 如何丢弃数据来创建更小的文件吗？ RAW 文件保留所有这些数据。这意味着您保留所有颜色数据，并以高光和阴影细节的方式保留所有内容。

此外，虽然相机在创建 JPEG 时会添加处理，但在创建 RAW 文件时不会发生这种情况。这意味着您可以控制整个过程。您可以添加您想要的任何级别的清晰度、对比度、饱和度等（当然，假设您可以访问 RAW 处理程序）。相机不会为你做出这些决定。

当然，RAW 文件更大，但效果更好。稍后您可以随时从 RAW 文件创建 JPEG ，完成编辑后可以使用该文件在线共享照片。

同时拍摄 RAW 和 JPEG

所以 RAW 文件是正确的选择，对吗？您将保留所有颜色数据，更不用说高光和阴影细节了。您可以完全控制图片的处理。这一定是值得的，对吧？

一般来说，这是事实：RAW 文件值得创建。但如果您根本不打算处理照片怎么办？然后以 JPEG 格式拍摄是否有意义，因为从相机中出来的文件看起来效果最好？或者，如果您需要立即分享照片，但没有时间进行任何编辑，该怎么办？

这就是为什么我鼓励您同时拍摄 RAW 和 JPEG 文件！您的相机可能有一个设置，允许您同时执行这两种操作 - 这样每次拍照时，相机都会创建一个 RAW 文件和一个 JPEG 文件。这将使您拥有两种文件类型的所有优点。

这对你有什么好处？以下是RAW+JPEG拍摄的优点：

  • 您有一个 JPEG 可以立即使用。假设您的相机中有 Wi-Fi，或者想要快速将图像传输到计算机并立即共享照片。 JPEG 对此很有意义。 RAW 文件则不然。它们不容易分享，而且从相机里出来的效果也不是最好的。
  • 它使照片能够面向未来。如果您使用佳能相机创建 RAW 文件，但 10 年后佳能倒闭了怎么办？随着时间的推移，您的 RAW 文件会失去支持吗？这似乎不太可能，但 Adob​​e 一直在推出自己的跨平台解决方案，称为 DNG（数字负片），这已经是一个大问题了。如果您有 JPEG，那么这不太可能成为问题。虽然一些相机现在提供以 HEIC 格式拍摄的选项（类似于 JPEG，但在图像质量方面更出色），但 JPEG 仍然更受欢迎且得到更好的支持。
  • 您可以看到相机如何处理文件。如果计算机上的 RAW 文件旁边有 JPEG，您可以看到相机决定如何处理照片。换句话说，您可以看到添加了多少锐化、对比度和饱和度，如果您喜欢， 可以在自己进行处理时模仿该效果。当您刚刚开始并尝试决定向照片添加多少处理时，这可能会很有帮助。
  • 您可以获得准确的 LCD 预览。当您在 LCD 上查看照片时，您会看到该照片的 JPEG 版本，即使您实际上是以 RAW 格式拍摄的。您可以通过“图片样式”添加不同的处理效果，包括黑白，并且无论如何您都会看到这些效果 - 但如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，当您将文件导入 Lightroom 或 Capture One 等程序时，这些效果将会消失。但是，如果您同时拍摄 RAW 和 JPEG，则相机将生成添加了效果的 JPEG 以及不添加效果的 RAW。因此，如果您想在保持 RAW 文件完整性的同时查看效果，那么捕获两者可能会有所帮助。

为什么不只拍摄RAW？

但等一下，你可能会想。当然，这些 JPEG 优势相当小，特别是如果您无论如何都打算编辑图像的话。何必为这一切烦恼呢？为什么不直接用 RAW 格式拍摄呢？

是的，JPEG 的优势很小，但与此同时，成本是多少？几乎什么也没有。随着时间的推移，数据变得越来越便宜。添加 JPEG 几乎不需要任何成本。现在的存储卡可以保存数百甚至数千张照片，而且它们现在非常便宜。现在您可以花费大约 35 美元购买一张 64 GB 的卡。您只需 200 美元即可获得可存储 TB 数据的硬盘。这些价格继续下降。与 RAW 文件相比，JPEG 占用的空间很小。因此，虽然我同意添加 JPEG 对于大多数拍摄者来说并没有太大的好处，但它也没有太大的缺点。

然而，还有一个方面我没有提到，那就是速度。请记住，您的相机必须将所有数据写入您的卡。如果您一次拍摄几张照片（或一次一张），这将不是一个因素。但如果您拍摄体育运动或野生动物，非常需要每秒最大帧数，那么就会产生额外的费用。写入附加文件的时间会减慢您的速度。在这种情况下，我绝对可以想象放弃额外的文件并选择仅以 RAW 格式拍摄。但对于我们大多数人来说，这并不适用。

为什么不只拍摄 JPEG？

与此同时，也有一些摄影师会想，“好吧，我不处理我的照片，所以我还不如直接拍摄 JPEG，以便直接从相机中获得最好看的文件。”

对于那些不处理图片的人，我首先要说：“你一定要处理一下！”您不需要做出巨大的改变或让您的图像看起来超现实，但您可以通过一些小调整来创造奇迹。

无论如何，仅仅因为您现在不对图片进行任何处理并不意味着您永远不会处理您的图片。一两年后，你可能会改变主意。当这种情况发生时，您不想因为没有获得最好的文件而自责。不，您不需要仅以 RAW 格式进行拍摄，这对于不打算进行编辑的人来说会很不方便，但 RAW+JPEG 是一种理想的方法。

RAW+JPEG 是两全其美！

我已经拍摄 RAW+JPEG 好几年了。我真的使用 JPEG 吗？几乎从不。我总是编辑 RAW 文件，通常不碰 JPEG 文件。

然而，如前所述，JPEG 不会花费我任何费用，因此我坚持使用此设置。另外，有几次我在路上想直接从相机发送照片，所以手头的 JPEG 确实很有用。

什么是地面吊舱？

地面吊舱是一个盘子/托盘，当您在污垢，泥浆或沙子中射击时，可以使您的相机保持稳定和移动状态。

您可以将相机连接到吊舱的中心，或者 - 为了提高灵活性 - 您可以将三脚架头拧到地面吊舱上，然后将相机连接到头部。它可以支撑您的相机离地面仅几英寸，从而提供一些防水或沙子/泥浆的保护，同时也可以轻松地在各个方向上移动。

现在，地面吊舱的好处是，它使您可以捕获野生动植物的低角度照片，而无需获得污垢覆盖的相机或镜头。但是作为摄影师，您仍然会变得肮脏！吊舱不会保护您免受泥浆的侵害，只有您的相机设置；那是野生动植物摄影乐趣的一部分！

创建DIY地面吊舱：我的过程

我想要一个地面吊舱，可以让我捕获低角度的野生动植物镜头，但是当我寻找市售的选择时，我很失望地看到它们的价格约为100美元。因此，我决定自己做！

我当然不是第一个这样做的人，但是我想分享如何做到这一点，以说明做出自己的低级相机支持的容易。

材料

正如我上面说的那样，DIY地面吊舱的材料根本不应该花很多钱。你会需要：

  1. 一个廉价的煎锅，直径约10-12英寸。您可以选择任何直径的煎锅适合您，但是更宽的锅将提供更多的支持，尤其是在使用较大的远摄镜头时。锅的深度应大约1-1.5英寸 - 任何更深的锅都会使调节三脚架的头部更加尴尬，但是任何较浅的人都可以更少的保护防水，泥浆和沙子。
  2. 3/8英寸的插座头螺栓，长度约为0.5英寸。圆头或桁架头螺栓是可取的。如果平底锅足够厚，则是一个pontersunk头是理想的。但是，廉价的平底锅通常太薄而无法实现。注意：在某些国际五金店中，很难在帝国大小的螺栓中搭配，因此，如果您位于美国以外，则可能涉及一些互联网搜索。
  3. 三脚架头。这在技术上是可选的。您可以将相机直接连接到地面吊舱，但是它会限制您的拍摄动作，并且在试图确保镜头清除垫唇部时，您也可能会遇到问题。因此，我喜欢使用三脚架的头（并且我要记住三脚架头写这篇文章）。如果您还没有三脚架头，则可以在eBay上找到便宜的球头，并且在尺寸和灵活性之间将是一个很好的折衷方案。您不想要太高的任何东西（它会击败试图变得如此低的一点），而且您也不希望用超宽的杠杆（这会在锅内笨拙）。如果您没有三脚架头可以使用，并且不想购买，则可以尝试使用几块木头来充当上升器，以确保镜头清除锅的边缘）。我还要指出，我上面提到的市售球头的价格（约100美元左右）不包括三脚架头，因此，即使您选择走非疾病的路线，您仍然需要采购一个头。
  4. 一个动力钻，可以使一个足够大的孔用于3/8英寸螺栓。
  5. 与十六进制螺栓中的插座相同的六角键/艾伦键。
  6. 当不使用锅时，将机翼螺母拧到螺栓上，以免丢失螺栓。任何类型的螺母都可以工作，但是机翼螺母足够大，难以丢失并且易于用冷手使用！

制作地面豆荚

豆荚的构造非常简单：

  1. 首先，从煎锅中卸下手柄。从平底锅上拧下螺钉应该很容易，然后将其拆下会使锅的形状不那么尴尬。您很可能会拧上一个小的，铆接的支架，将手柄拧到（请参见上面的图像！）；但是，这是一个方便的小地方，可以使用登山扣将油炸锅钩在相机袋上，因此您不必手工携带它。

邮政自动白平衡：您应该真的将其用于摄影吗？首先出现在数码摄影学校。它由Nisha Ramroop撰写。

对于摄影师来说， 白平衡可能是要掌握的最棘手的概念之一。即使您了解了基础知识，决定正确的白平衡设置也很困难。您的相机可能拥有一系列选项，包括白平衡预设（例如，日光，多云，钨）和手动开尔文值。

但是您的相机可能会提供另一种设置：自动白平衡或AWB。

自动白平衡肯定听起来很吸引人 - 与其名称一致，一旦将相机设置为AWB设置，它将自动为场景选择白平衡 - 但是AWB的确有多好？您应该在野外拍摄时信任它，还是应该在不同的设置中工作，即使需要更多的努力？

这就是我要在本文中回答的目标。下面，我解释了什么是自动白平衡；我还探索了它的好处和局限性，并为您何时使用AWB提出了建议 - 何时您应该避免使用AWB。

让我们开始吧！

快速概述白平衡

在对自动白平衡的讨论太深入之前，我想确保我们都在同一页面上更广泛地了解白平衡。

那么白平衡到底是什么，为什么对数码摄影如此重要？

基本的答案是，光（摄影的基础）在一天中的不同时间具有可变的颜色温度。与数码相机相比，您的眼睛在处理颜色方面要好得多。因此，白色对象总是会出现白色，而不同类型的光线的白色物体不会总是使您的相机看起来为白色，从而导致不自然的颜色铸件。

（尽管人造灯也可以产生绿色和紫色的铸件，但这些颜色铸件通常沿着自然界的蓝黄色频谱存在。）

现在，白平衡是相机用来删除这些有问题的颜色铸件的过程。当您将相机设置为白平衡设置时，您将确保它有效地抵消了不自然的温度和色彩 - 以便您的图像更紧密地反映您的眼睛所看到的。

什么是自动白平衡（AWB）？

自动白平衡（AWB）是一个相机设置，它告诉您的相机“猜测”最佳的白平衡选项。换句话说，当您将相机设置为AWB时，它会分析场景，并试图选择使您的照片看起来自然的白平衡。

（这类似于相机的自动曝光设置，在该设置中，相机试图确定理想的光圈，快门速度和ISO值以创建详细的图像。

以我的经验，自动白平衡可以起作用，但是当您在户外处理自然照明时通常会更有效，并且在处理复杂的照明情况时，它往往会挣扎。

AWB如何工作？

要了解何时应该使用自动白平衡，您必须对相机提供的不同白平衡的基本知识。这些可能会因相机品牌而异，但通常包括日光，多云，阴影，钨和荧光。添加到这些是Flash，kelvin和自定义白平衡。

注意：当您特别具有挑战性的照明条件并需要完美地确定白平衡时，应使用自定义的白平衡模式。它使您可以将相机指向图像的中性部分，然后创建自定义的白平衡效果，以抵消场景中施放的任何颜色。这是一个未充分利用的选择，可以很好地效果，因此请检查您的手册并进行尝试。

现在，自动白平衡设置评估您的场景，并选择图像中最亮的部分作为白点。然后它平衡了场景，以确保此选定的白点看起来完全中立。

不幸的是，您的相机选择的白点可以从一张镜头到另一个镜头，这可能导致具有非常不同颜色铸件的图像序列。因此，拍摄全景时使用自动白平衡是一个坏主意。如果您的相机改变了Panorama系列中间的白平衡，则结果看起来非常奇怪！

自动白平衡带有另一个问题：您的相机可以锁定在镜头的区域上，该区域并不是中立的（例如，黄色的墙壁），然后尝试平衡它。当这种情况发生时，您的相机将创建一些自己的相机，而不是中和颜色铸件！

这是个好消息：虽然自动白平衡并不完美，但已对AWB系统进行了重大改进，并且结果越来越好。尽管如此，自动白平衡很难处理某些类型的照明（例如，人造或组合照明设置）。

还值得一提的是，您有时可以遇到另一个问题，AWB消除了要保留的颜色。当您拍摄日落或光线颜色对图像必不可少的任何场景时，这可能会发生。

原始力量

如果您以RAW拍摄，您可能会意识到RAW文件保留了相机捕获的所有颜色数据。此保留带有巨大的好处：它使您可以在后处理原始文件的同时更改或选择其他白平平衡设置。

因此，许多摄影师认为，只要您以RAW拍摄，就可以使用自动白平衡而无需任何问题。 （尽管其他人认为即使在RAW进行拍摄时， AWB也不会给您最好的颜色。）

即使我们批准在后处理过程中可以有效地平衡原始文件，但我仍然认为您不应该一直使用它。

设置白平衡摄像机内的白平衡可确保在所有镜头中（例如，拍摄婚礼时）的颜色再现是一致的，并且它使后处理变得更加容易，尤其是如果您有很多要编辑的文件。

另外，即使拍摄同一场景，AWB也可以为您提供不同的结果。如果您使用的变焦镜头，则可能会在广角拍摄中获得一组颜色 - 然后，当您放大远摄特写镜头时，最终会带有不同的颜色。当然，您可以在进行后处理时更正所有内容，但是从一开始就可以立即获得白平衡通常更容易。

控制相机的白平衡设置！

您可能需要使用自动白平衡，因为让相机根据您面前的场景更容易弄清楚正确的设置。但是，正如我上面解释的那样，这并不总是最好的方法。有时，稍后，您可以通过钉住现场的白平衡来节省很多挫败感。 （如果您曾经拍摄过jpegs，那么您绝对想确保正确获得白平衡；它们的灵活性与RAWS的灵活性不会。）

幸运的是，设定白平衡并不像听起来那样令人生畏。而且，当照明条件不变时，您只需要设置一次白平衡（对于这些条件）即可。这里有一些快速建议：

如果您在晴天的户外活动，请将白平衡设置为日光或阳光明媚。如果多云，请选择多云的白平衡。同样，如果您处于阴影状态，请选择阴影。这些非常容易根据他们的名字来记住！

在室内时，请选择钨（或白炽灯）以获取白炽灯。当用荧光灯拍摄区域时，请选择荧光。

这只是设定白平衡以符合您的拍摄条件。

您还可以设置白平衡来修改现有条件。一旦开始实验白平衡并了解它如何影响图像，您就可以使用它来发挥创造力并使镜头看起来更温暖或更酷。

只要您以RAW拍摄，您就可以随时在Lightroom，捕获一个或另一个编辑器中进行调整。但是，知道如何与相机的各种白平衡设置一起使用，并结合后处理工具将使您成为更有效的摄影师！

您应该使用自动白平衡吗？

简短的答案是：是的，有时。

更长的答案是，当您不确定对场景有效的白平衡时，自动白平衡是一个方便的环境。如果您以RAW拍摄，则可以在事实之后轻松更改白平衡，以找到最佳选择。当您在快速变化的照明条件下拍照时，AWB也可能很有用，或者只是不介意在后处理照片时仔细调整白平衡。

但是，如果您想更多地控制结果，请选择一个已经针对特定条件量身定制的相机白色平衡预设，或使用自定义的白平衡来自定义特定场景的设置。在现场设置白平衡将消除将其在场景之间固定的额外后处理步骤，并为您提供更一致的结果。

在Instagram或Flickr上滚动，您经常会遇到令人难以置信的花朵，昆虫或珠宝的特写照片。而且，如果您像我一样，您可能会想知道：如何获得像这些照片？

如果您拥有专用的无反光镜相机或数码单反相机，那么基本的答案是投资宏观镜头或其他关闭的辅助工具，然后学习宏观摄影的技巧。

但是，如果您尚未拥有相机，或者您不想投资重型设备，那么您还有另一种选择：

您可以深入研究移动宏摄影，在那里您可以使用手机上的相机创建惊人的特写照片。

我完全认真：只要您拥有手机，简单的配件和一些好奇心，就可以捕获令人惊叹的移动宏照片。实际上，一旦您了解了一些基本技术，就没有人能猜测您使用智能手机而不是$ 1000+相机拍摄图像。

因此，在本文中，我将浏览一些技巧，以帮助您使用手机获得惊人的宏观照片。我还将分享一些自己的移动宏摄影，因此您确切知道您口袋里的那个相机的能力！

选择完美的智能手机宏观镜头

一些智能手机提供了宏观模式，它将使您合理地接近主题。但是，以我的经验，使用手机获得惊人宏观照片的绝对最佳方法是投资于夹在手机相机上的廉价镜头（或一组镜头）。

当我第一次探索手机宏观摄影时，我购买了Olloclip 4 in-1套装，其中包括几种夹式镜头，包括两种宏观型号：10倍和15倍。

我很快发现10倍宏观镜头是我个人的最爱，因为它适合我的大多数主题。因此，我还得到了Olloclip Macro 3合1套件，该镜头提供了7倍，14倍和21倍放大倍率，以及几个特殊的引擎盖，可以扩散照明，并使射门更加容易。

随着时间的流逝，我发现7倍镜头是我几乎所有宏观照片的首选，因为它可以捕获足够大的区域，同时仍然获得很多细节。您可能会有不同的感觉，因此为您的智能手机投资一些不同的夹具镜头，然后尝试不同的宏伟镜头，直到找到自己喜欢的镜头！

不幸的是，Olloclip暂停了其操作，因此发现这些镜头变得更加艰难。如果您特别想购买Olloclip产品，则可以在Amazon或eBay上环顾四周 - 尽管Amazon上还有许多其他出色的手机宏观镜头。 （您还必须注意手机的兼容性；由于Olloclip不再生产其产品，因此最近的一些电话模型可能与较旧的Olloclip宏观镜头无法正常工作。）

无论如何，肯定还有其他品牌和大型品牌，但是请确保您购买的镜头搭配手机，并且不会妨碍拍照。请注意，大多数镜头在手机上滑动，因此通常不能将其与手机盒一起使用。一些公司提供特殊情况，并在相机区域周围开放，以便于访问，尽管需要使用某些移动宏观配件而无需使用任何情况。

您永远不知道何时可能会遇到一个很棒的宏观主题，所以我建议您随身携带镜头（它们适合口袋），尤其是当您出门时。这是一个很好的习惯，当您刚开始时，它会让您尝试不同的主题。

（一个花园或其他带有鲜花或昆虫的区域是尝试新镜头的好地方。

正确灯

与所有形式的摄影一样，照明对于拍摄良好的宏观图片至关重要。换句话说，如果您想要良好的移动宏镜头，则必须学会利用光线来发挥自己的优势！

我个人喜欢在日光下拍摄 - 它通常很明亮易于使用 - 但是中午太阳呈现出棘手的阴影，这可能会使创建好的图像很难。有了宏观摄影，您有时可以通过轻轻弯曲花茎或向您转动叶子来移动主题以减少阴影。

您也可以使用身体来阻挡明亮的阳光，或者将手放在主题上以减少眩光。

另一个选择是在黄金时段（日出和日落）射击；虽然灯光往往不那么明亮，虽然您有时需要注意偶然地在主题上施放不必要的阴影，但柔软的光可以很好地补充花朵和昆虫。

一个技巧：如果您在天空中的太阳低时射击，则可以在图像的背景中捕获一点点阳光。当您使用宏观镜头接近主题时，背景灯通常会以散景的形式变成可爱的照片，或者使您的图片看起来显得发光的焦点区域：

小心地聚焦并构架宏观镜头

有了宏观照片，有无穷无尽的方法可以构建主题，但是您可以使用非常有限的景深（即，照片的区域将保持焦点为焦点）。

我通常希望该主题（主要是）焦点，但是景深的程度取决于晶状体的放大倍率。放大倍数越大，图片中精确焦点的区域越小。对于许多初学者来说，这可能会令人沮丧 - 但是我认为，这通常会导致令人惊讶的美丽照片，您可能不会只从手机中获得。

此外，智能手机的宏观镜头通常限制您的特写焦点。结果是，即使使用较低的宏观镜头（例如，7倍oloclip），您的预期受试者也可能太大而无法全部捕获。

例如，您可能必须专注于主题的一部分 - 例如花的中心或几瓣。那是宏观摄影的有趣部分！您可以从上方，侧面甚至从下方射击主题。试验同一主题的不同角度。

拍照时静止不动

拍摄宏观照片时，运动是您的敌人。即使在拍摄时轻微移动也会导致模糊。您将需要保持非常静止的状态，您还需要竭尽所能，以防止主题移动。

手机的三脚架可以提供帮助，但这不是必需的。只需找到一个舒适的位置，尽可能保持静止，并用两只手稳固手机。

有时，就像在轻松的一天一样，不可能将您的主题放在一个地方。有时您可以保持主题（例如，在拍摄花朵时），但是其他时候您无法（例如，拍摄昆虫时）。对于这些情况，一个有用的提示是使用手机相机上的突发模式，该模式在快速连续的情况下进行了许多镜头。

在iPhone上，您可以按下手机侧面的相机按钮或屏幕上的镜头，以迅速拍摄多张照片。 Android手机通常也可以做到这一点。如果您没有内置的爆发最多，只需在尽可能静止的同时拍摄很多照片即可。这就是我获得大部分昆虫照片的方式：通过耐心和拍摄许多照片。我稍后清除模糊的照片。

The post Model Releases in Photography: What You Need to Know (With Samples) appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Jeff Guyer .

When I quit practicing law ten years ago, I knew I was trading in my briefcase for a camera bag and the courtroom for a studio. I had no idea, however, that contracts would continue to dominate so much of my time.

The importance of the contract between you and your client is pretty much a given, but just as important – if not even more important – is the model release. If you've been shooting professionally for any period of time, you already know (I hope) that securing a model release from the people you photograph is absolutely essential.

What you may not be aware of, however, is why it is so important. It is an unfortunate reality that most people neither completely read nor understand the legal documents they sign or have prepared for them. You may have an iron-clad model release in your bag of tricks, but you may not understand what exactly it's releasing or the significance of the language.

Having a fuller understanding of the basics will help you greatly in the long run, particularly when assessing whether you even need a model release, and convincing your subject to sign one if you do.

What is a model release, and why is it important?

At its most basic, a model release is a contract: a written and signed agreement between you and the person you are photographing.

The purpose of a model release is to protect – ie, release – you from liability in future lawsuits that your subject/model might file against you for legal claims like invasion of privacy, defamation of character, etc.

The document stipulates the terms under which one party may use photos taken of another party. Model releases are usually brief – no more than a paragraph – but they can get quite long, especially if the model wants to add additional conditions to the release (eg, no Photoshop).

We'll get into the specific contents of the model release in a bit. For now, though, know that a model release is a crucial piece of paper for any photograph that's used commercially.

How do I know if I need a model release?

Not all photoshoots that include people require model releases, so it's important to start by understanding whether a release is necessary for the type of photography you'll be doing.

You should always start with a basic premise:

Whether you need a model release does not primarily depend on the content of the image. Rather, it depends on the image's use .

When you start with this premise – that the need is primarily dictated by the use and not the content – you are left with a pretty basic set of questions:

Question 1: Will the photo be used commercially?

The first question you should ask when determining the importance of a model release is “Will this photo be used commercially?” If the answer is “Yes,” you need a model release. If the answer is “No,” you do not need a model release.很简单，对吧？不完全的！ （继续阅读。）

Just because an image is published does not, in and of itself, automatically mean that the use is commercial. For instance, work that will only appear in newspapers, educational books, and consumer or trade publications does not need a model release because it is editorial use, sometimes referred to as “fair use.”

Commercial usage, on the other hand, can include advertisements, brochures, web use, greeting cards, catalogs, newsletters, etc. For commercial, licensed use, you absolutely, positively must have a model release.

What is and isn't commercial use can sometimes be confusing. Assume that you have taken a photo of a popular local chef, but you haven't obtained a signed model release. Your friend is the publisher of a local newspaper and he pays you for the photograph for use in an article they are running about the restaurant. Because the photo is being used as part of a news story, this constitutes editorial use. The fact that money changed hands does not automatically render it a commercially used photograph, and the lack of a model release isn't a problem.

If, however, the restaurant's PR agency wants to use the same photo as part of an ad campaign, you will need a model release. Remember, whether a model release is necessary depends on the use, not the content – here, we're talking about the same photo, but with two different uses. One needs the release and one does not. Ultimately, there is no way of knowing whether you need a model release until you can answer the question of how the photo will be used .

The examples below illustrate the importance of the intended use when determining whether you need a model release. The protest image (on the left) was taken as part of a news story about cuts to the state budget for publicly funded art programs. It was editorial use, and therefore no model release was required. The chess game photo (top right) was for a commercial publication on local tourism. It required a model release for its original use, though it does not require a model release for its editorial publication here on dPS. The crowd shot at the bottom appeared in a news article about public education, which, as you now know, requires no model release.

Question 2: Is the subject of the image identifiable?

If you have determined that the use will indeed be commercial, the next question you have to answer is whether the person in the photo is uniquely recognizable and clearly the subject of the photo.

If the person is not uniquely identifiable, there is no need for a model release. But just like the shifting boundaries mentioned above, what does and does not constitute “uniquely identifiable” is not always cut and dry. Remember, there are ways to identify or recognize someone in a photo other than just their face. Sometimes a silhouette, a tattoo, a uniform, or even a location can identify a person without necessarily showing their face – and in those situations, you'll still need a model release.

At first glance, the three photos below appear to have no recognizable subjects, which might lead you to think that model releases wouldn't be necessary, regardless of whether the image use was commercial or editorial.

Let's assume that all three images are indeed designated for commercial use. As far as the Parkview High School students (the top image) are concerned, let's face it: parents and friends can identify each student easily, body paint, wigs, and sunglasses notwithstanding.

Tattoos (bottom left) are also fairly distinctive, rendering it a moot point that you can't see the tattoo artist's face in the photograph. The ink on her arms could be enough for someone to recognize her.

Finally, the artist in the park can theoretically be recognized, not because of anything distinctive about her from this angle, but because of the distinctive nature of her painting.

In other words, all three of the example images will require a model release, plain and simple (assuming they're going to be used commercially).

Question 3: How and where was the photo taken?

At first glance, it doesn't seem like this question should make a difference, but it does. This is where things like travel, candid, and street photography come into play. Photos I take in public places – streets, fairs, parks, festivals, etc. – generally do not require model releases, especially if they're destined to reside only in my portfolio or on my walls.

Again, however, if I think there's even a chance that I might someday want to use that photo commercially (see the first question!), I have to get a model release. That's why I always suggest that photographers play it safe and get a model release whenever someone is recognizable and clearly the subject of the photo. You just never know what money-making images might be lurking in your archives until someone comes looking for them. It's always easier to get the model release first rather than to retrace your steps later and hope for the best.

In this final set of examples, we see how photos taken in public places may or may not require model releases. As noted, street photography – regardless of recognizable faces – will not require releases unless they are intended for commercial use. From a legal standpoint, you can photograph anyone in a public setting, as long as you are not violating any other laws by doing so. That doesn't mean it's always a good idea, but that doesn't make it illegal.

(Note: This does vary by location, and while it's legal to photograph in public settings within the United States, it may not be true in other parts of the world – so always check the local laws before doing people photography in an unfamiliar location. ）

When photographing children under the age of 18 for commercial purposes, however, a parent or legal guardian must sign the model release. Getting the minor's signature doesn't count.

What is commercial use? A simple definition

Simply put, commercial use is that which is intended to enhance a business interest. I listed some common commercial uses earlier, but it all boils down to whether someone's use of the photos in question is aimed at generating revenue.

When I photograph an author for their book cover, it is clearly commercial. In addition to appearing on the back of the book, the photo may appear in advertisements for the book. It might also appear in bookstore windows promoting the book, the author's appearance at signings, and other promotional events. All of this activity is clearly aimed at making money, so identifying commercial use is pretty simple.

What complicates the issue, however, is the photo you take for no reason other than to post it in one of the galleries on your professional website. Clearly, you're not selling the actual image, so no money is changing hands. You are, however, using that person's likeness as an example of the type of work you do in order to hopefully bring in more business. Your interest in using the photo is clearly commercial in nature.

There is no actual monetary gain from the image itself in this context, so the lines are blurred, but you do have a commercial goal in featuring it on your website. The same reasoning applies to hanging client photos in your studio. There is a commercial benefit to the extent that displaying samples of your work will encourage other potential clients to hire you. It is much better to err on the side of caution and have your subject sign a model release than to spend your time defending against lawsuits and cease & desist letters.

What should a model release say?

This is where a bit of a disclaimer is in order:

A model release is a contract. Most of the applicable principles are widely accepted, but laws do vary from state to state and from country to country. There are many excellent resources for creating model releases out there, so I strongly caution against simply writing your own document. Why reinvent the wheel if you don't have to? If you have questions or are unsure about any aspect of this, play it smart and consult with an attorney.

The most basic tenet of contract law is that there must be a “meeting of the minds.” In other words, a valid contract is a two-way street, obligating each party in some way. Hand in hand with this requirement is that of “consideration.” In a legal context, “consideration” simply means something of value. As the photographer, you are asking the person you are photographing to surrender any right or claim they may have to how, where, and when these photos are used. That can be a big deal, and you should be prepared to offer them something of value in return. It can be a nominal sum of money, it can be prints, or it can be something else to which the two of you can agree. Contracts have been upheld for consideration as low as one dollar. The model release must acknowledge this consideration.

It is also important to remember that the photographer is hardly ever the actual publisher of the photo. The model release must therefore indicate that the subject is not only consenting to your use of the photos, but also that of whomever you authorize to use the photos.

Let's go back to our example photo of the chef. Assume that the chef's agent or publicist hired you to photograph the chef for the cover of their upcoming cookbook. Obviously, you are not the publisher. You will, however, be licensing the photo for use by the publisher. The only way you can do so is to make sure that the model release authorizes you to grant usage rights to a third party.

As noted, a model release can – and should – be short, sweet, and to the point. I keep a stack of this model release printed on 3″x5″ card stock in my camera bag. It's short enough to be effective and valid, and it doesn't confuse the subject to the point that they refuse to sign it. I rely on this short release for more spur-of-the-moment photography, whereas I use this longer version for commissioned work.

One additional note on the paperwork: keep it forever. Model releases aren't records you can throw out after a certain amount of time. You will need the release if you ever want to license the image. And more importantly, you'll need to release to defend yourself if you are ever sued.

Model releases matter!

Some people may be hesitant, or even unwilling, to sign a model release. You have to be prepared to respect that decision . It is certainly easier to get a person to sign a release when you have been hired to take their photos, rather than when you are roaming the streets, just shooting what interests you.

I always make sure that my clients sign the release before we start the shoot – assuming that a release is needed in the first place! Keep in mind that what can seem like a complicated process can be easily broken down into a fairly quick analysis. Ask yourself if the photo is going to be used commercially in any way. If the answer is “No,” the inquiry stops right there and you are free to hang that photo as big as you want on your living room wall. If you think, though, that there is any chance that you might one day want to license the photo for commercial use, obtaining a signed model release is an absolute necessity.

For most of us, photography is a fun and joyful activity, one where we get to do something we enjoy and share it with others. Indeed, all the time and all over the world, professional photographers are asked to immortalize the happiest times of people's lives: beginnings of families and lives, important rituals, celebrated accomplishments. Photographing a funeral is very different – on many levels.

Although a funeral may not seem like the kind of event people would seek to remember, it often is. After all, it's an important ritual, a celebration of a life, and a gathering of people who may not know each other well, but who are united in their mourning.

In my experience, many people find it important to have their loved one's funeral documented, even though it's a photography service that isn't advertised or discussed as much or in the same way as others (eg, senior portraits, family photoshoots, etc) 。

Photographing a funeral: what you need to know

Note: All the images in this article have been approved for use here by the families. No images have been used without written permission for this sensitive subject matter.

To some extent, preparing to photograph a funeral differs little from any other photography job. But there are obviously some unique considerations, and in this article, I'll discuss both the similarities and the important differences.

One thing I want to emphasize:

Don't photograph a funeral as your first photography job, or even as your second. Funeral photography requires a professional and calm attitude, a lot of experience, and high-quality work. It's important that it's done correctly – so if you've been asked to document a funeral and you've never really done any serious event photography before, you should gently encourage the client to ask someone with more photoshoots under their belt. (At the very least, emphasize that you've never done something like this before; you want to make sure they know what they're getting.)

葬礼前

The funeral is a foundational life-cycle event, and for the person looking to hire you, it undoubtedly brings up a lot of emotions.

Funeral photography isn't discussed as much as other types of photography – there are no magazines or fairs about it, and there's little sharing of funeral photos on social media. Therefore, good communication with the client is even more important than usual. Remember that the person you're dealing with may not be able to express exactly what they're looking for, and that they will naturally be stressed and upset.

So make sure you ask lots of questions, and try to offer input and advice if the client seems to be struggling. Of course, you should do all this with the utmost sensitivity; the goal isn't to show off your professionalism or expertise but to understand what to expect and what the client wants.

If possible, take some photos before the mourners enter. That way, you can capture the wider scene. Always ask before entering, though.

Here are the most important things to find out before the day of the funeral:

  • When and where will the ceremony take place? If possible, visit the place beforehand to familiarize yourself with the venue. (When you're there, scope out the light situation. Think about how the lighting might change depending on the weather and the time of day, especially if the venue includes large windows.)
  • What kind of ceremony will it be? If you'll be photographing a ceremony that's unfamiliar to you, make sure you learn all you can about it. This is for a few key reasons: so you can have a better sense of what will happen on the day, so you can know which elements of the ceremony are most important (and should therefore be most carefully documented), and so you can avoid doing anything inappropriate or disrespectful while photographing. Also, if you feel you can't confidently photograph a certain ceremony by the date of the funeral, communicate that to your client right away so they can find someone else instead. As I emphasized above, funeral photography must be done well, and if you're not sure you're up to the task, it's not the time to shrug and say, “Well, I'll do my best!”
  • What specific photographs are particularly important to the client? For instance, some might want you to focus on the sermon and the eulogy, while others might ask you to prioritize photos of the mourners or the religious details.
  • What kind of relationship does the customer have with the deceased?

On the day of the funeral, wear something dark (and make sure that it's appropriate for the ceremony, based on your questions and research). Also, wear shoes that will let you move around without causing a disturbance.

Naturally, be sure to be at the venue on time, greet your client, and offer your condolences.

Photographing the ceremony

The biggest challenge when photographing a funeral is finding the right balance between getting beautiful photos and not disturbing the ceremony. Make sure to be quiet and to avoid blocking the mourners' view, but remember that you're being paid to capture the event. Your client has asked you to help family and friends remember a momentous day and the life of a loved one, so you must do your job, and you must do it well.

Look for areas of the space that allow you to create meaningful images while staying out of people's way – this is another way that visiting the venue in advance can be a big help – and whatever you do, don't work with a flash. Also, if your camera has a silent or electronic shooting mode, then use it; most modern mirrorless cameras offer this option, and it'll often make your shutter imperceptible. Keep noisy adjustments (like lens changes) to an absolute minimum – if you want to switch between focal lengths, carry two cameras, or use a high-quality zoom .

The photos you absolutely must capture depend on the kind of ceremony in question, and they also depend on the client's desires. However, here are a few general types of images that you should strive to take:

  • Mourners paying their respects
  • The essential parts of the religious (if it is religious) ceremony
  • The burial and final goodbyes

You've been asked to photograph a very intimate event, so remember that photographing the guests should be done discreetly and with respect. To many, images of the guests are some of the most important that you'll capture: they signify different parts of the deceased person's rich life and represent the people in whose memories the deceased will continue to live on. Some might want a group photo of all the guests (if you're not sure whether this is of interest, ask in advance).

The details and specific parts of the ceremony are also important to photograph: the flower arrangements, the lowering of the coffin, and the priest or leader of the ceremony.

葬礼结束后

When the ceremony (or the part of it you have been asked to photograph) is over, let your client know you're leaving, offer your condolences once again, and compliment them on how beautiful the event was.

Immediately afterward, go home, and back up your photos. Then give yourself a breather and take care of yourself. Being a part of this kind of event might affect you more than you realize.

The image-selection process and editing should happen the way it always does. You should be professional and deliver the images in a timely manner. Just remember to be very respectful and create the most tasteful pictures you can. If you're not sure whether an image is tasteful/appropriate, it's better to leave it out of the set you deliver to your client.

Be respectful, be professional, and accommodate the client

Funerals are events of sorrow, of remembering, and of togetherness. It's important to capture all of that, not only the darkness.

Most importantly, however, is to be empathetic throughout the entire process. The more you can focus on the client's needs, the more effectively you create the kind of images that your client is seeking – and the better it'll be for everyone.

There is nothing like having your photos displayed on a wall for everyone to see, admire, and appreciate.更好的是看到印刷品下面的那些小圆形红色贴纸，表明该作品已售出。

For most artists, exhibiting work is a driving force – and that's especially true of photographers who make images intended for walls and gallery displays.

But putting together a photography exhibition can be harder than you think. You have to consider an array of questions, such as:

  • Where should you exhibit your work?
  • How do you submit photos?
  • How do you price your work?
  • Do you purchase insurance?
  • How should you frame your photos (if at all)?

Exhibiting your work can also be very expensive, so it's important to understand the basic costs before you take the leap.

In this article, I aim to answer all of these questions (and more!). That way, if you do decide to move forward with an exhibition, you know how to make it as successful as possible.

Why do a photography exhibit?

Artists have been exhibiting their work for centuries, and today is no different – though some of the reasons for displaying your photos have changed.

Before the internet, exhibitions were one of the best ways to showcase your work, and artists used them to make money. They would invite special clients or benefactors to the openings, hoping they would buy one or a few pieces.

Selling art is harder these days, so if your sole reason for exhibiting is to sell your photos, then you may be very disappointed. However, if your goal is to put your work up on a wall to show people what you are capable of as an artist, then an exhibition can be very rewarding. Take it from me: Having all your best work up for everyone to see can feel like quite an achievement.

Another reason many artists exhibit is to put the exhibitions down on their artist's CV. The CV (or curriculum vitae) is a list of all your exhibitions, as well as your education and a few other things, similar to a résumé. It's what galleries look at when considering whether they'll show your work.

Costs and budgeting

Exhibitions are not cheap! Therefore, before you decide to go all-in on an exhibit, there are many factors you'll need to consider, including:

  • What sort of space will you exhibit in and how much will access cost?
  • What other expenses will there be?
  • How many images will you prepare for the exhibit, and what will the reproduction outlays cost?
  • Should you have a solo exhibition or start with group shows?

These are all questions you need to think about, and that I address in greater detail below.

Group vs solo exhibits

Solo shows are fantastic, and they're ultimately what every artist wants. (Imagine having an entire show dedicated to just your images!) But solo shows are also very expensive, especially because you won't have anyone with whom you can share the expenses.

Therefore, instead of diving headfirst into solo exhibiting, most artists start with group shows. Then, if they have some success, they move up to solo shows.

Group shows are a good way to get your feet wet and start building your artist's CV. There are a handful of different ways to get started with group shows, but I'd encourage you to find some friends who are also interested in exhibiting, then apply together to galleries to see if you can get an exhibition.

Many galleries also hold group shows of their own, and they'll often advertise for artists to participate – so you can often look out for those and apply!

Where to exhibit your photos

Honestly, you could probably create an endless list of exhibition possibilities, but the most common places are galleries that specialize in the type of work you create.

However, there are other places, like cafes or restaurants, that like to have exhibitions featuring different artwork on their walls. There are benefits and disadvantages to each of these approaches:

Exhibiting at cafes, restaurants, and foyers

These places often allow you to exhibit for free, and they don't always have schedules, so you can sometimes have your work up for longer than you could in a gallery.

Cafes and restaurants may not want a commission from the sale of work, but they may want you to handle all the sales, so you would need to leave contact information. And they usually won't take any responsibility for your art pieces, so be aware of that (in other words, loss and damage won't be covered).

When exhibiting at one of these places, you won't have access to a mailing list, and you'll have to do all the advertising yourself. People generally don't just wander in to look at the work; sure, the customers will see your images, but they're there for specific reasons (eg, to eat lunch), and buying images isn't one of them. While you can sell pieces from a cafe exhibit, your audience isn't there to buy what you are selling, which makes this type of show a bit more passive.

Your work will most likely need to be framed for hanging, and you will probably have to install it yourself at the exhibit space.

Exhibiting at galleries

There are many different types of galleries, and it's up to you to decide which type will work best for your photography. Here are the basic gallery categories to keep in mind:

Artist-run spaces

The cheapest spaces to use are generally artist-run. You pay less to show your work, but you are expected to “sit the exhibition.” That means you have to be there when the gallery is open to watch your work and manage any sales.

Attending the entire time the gallery is open can be time-consuming. Many artists will get together for a group show, split the costs of renting the space, and draw up a roster to sit the exhibition. For artists starting out, this can be a much better option. If you want to do a group show with a split schedule but don't know anyone to exhibit with, try contacting the gallery; they may know some artists looking to share a show.

While artist-run spaces don't come with hefty upfront fees, you'll need to take on most of the remaining expenses. The cost of the opening is covered and organized by you. You must also pay for most of the advertising, though some galleries will have a mailing list for you to use.

Staffed galleries

Staffed galleries are the next level. They cost more, but you are relieved of the burden of having to sit the exhibition.

There are two types of staffed galleries – commercial and non-commercial – and they often work in different ways.

Non-commercial galleries

These are often smaller galleries that charge you for renting the space and to sit the photography exhibit for you. They are often the most expensive galleries to use for an exhibition. Non-commercial galleries will help advertise the opening, but they are generally not interested in promoting you and your work beyond the exhibition; in other words, the relationship is short-term.

Non-commercial galleries make their money from your rental fee. They also take a commission from any work you sell (usually around 30%). These galleries are a good way to start getting work on your CV. Some also do a lot of group shows, so I'd recommend seeing if you can get work into them.

Non-commercial galleries aren't typically picky about what they exhibit, as long as the quality of work is good. They won't mind if one exhibition is all abstract paintings and the next is all landscape photographs. It can be a lot easier to get a show at one of these galleries than at the commercial galleries.

Commercial galleries

Commercial galleries are a lot harder to get exhibitions with. They have many artists to choose from and usually have a particular type of artist in mind. They're less interested in a short-term relationship, and are more interested in helping you establish yourself as one of their artists – in other words, they want to represent you.

Commercial galleries will keep some of your work in a stockroom and advertise what you do. They try to get collectors to view your work (so the collectors will begin collecting and supporting you, as well).

Commercial galleries usually represent a niche market. If you send your photos to a gallery that only deals with Indigenous art, they are not going to be interested. Therefore, when approaching these galleries, you need to do your research. Make sure your work fits in with the other artists they represent. At the same time, if they have another artist who does work that is almost the same as yours, then they're not going to be interested, either. The trick is to find galleries where your photos fit but are also somewhat unique.

Commercial galleries often cost a lot less for an exhibition. However, they are harder to get shows in and will take a higher commission. (Here in Australia, that rate is usually around 40%, compared to the 30% taken by non-commercial galleries.)

Submitting your work to galleries

Most galleries advertise when it's a good time to submit proposals. While you can send inquiries at other times, it is best to check their websites for submission dates (ie, times when they are asking people to send in exhibition proposals).

Commissions and pricing your work

All galleries charge a commission, and some cafes do, too. When pricing your work, you need to consider this amount. Make sure you find out the commission percentage when first inquiring about exhibiting in the space.

Also, when it comes to pricing, you should be realistic. If you are new to the art world, charging thousands of dollars for your work isn't feasible. Only established artists can command prices like that. To get an idea of what you can realistically charge, look at the space in which you'll be exhibiting and see how much previous artists have charged for similar work. If you are happy with the prices, you could try charging the same.

As your reputation grows and more people start buying your work, then you can consider charging more.

Handling loss due to damage or theft

When you rent a space to show your work, you also take on the responsibilities of it as well. Even galleries are unlikely to cover any theft or damage to your artwork.

This is often in the contract or terms. Make sure you are aware, and if you're worried, then insurance could be an option.

Insuring your work

As I said, most places will not cover your work if it's damaged or stolen. Therefore, insurance is something you need to consider when displaying your art. Do you need to purchase insurance? In truth, most artists don't worry about it, but that doesn't mean you should do the same. I'd recommend doing some research; see how much it will cost and if it feels worth it.

Now, if the work has cost you a lot of money to produce, then insurance is more important. You can also talk to the gallery and see if they have had problems in the past, especially with theft.

Also, if the work is going into a high-traffic zone, like a walkway, where it can be damaged or someone could walk off with it, then it's definitely worth considering.

At the end of the day, whether you get an insurance policy should depend on the work itself, but also on the exhibition space. If your work is displayed in a cafe, then the staff may not have the time to watch the work at all, especially during busy periods. A gallery is going to be in a better position to watch – but only if they have the staff. If you have to sit the space yourself, can you watch everything?

Should you frame your work?

Many places will answer the question of framing for you: They will either say the work has to be framed or that it can be pinned to the wall.

If the work has to be framed, then you must decide if that is something you can afford. Getting work custom-framed can be very expensive. For this reason, a lot of artists make all their work the same size (or use the same size frames and just alter the mat sizes according to the images). They then go to a place like Ikea and buy cheaper frames. If you do the framing yourself, then you can reuse the frames every time you want to do a show.

If you don't have to frame your prints and can pin the images on the wall, that doesn't mean you can't get the work framed. Again, you'll want to take your budget into account. However, if you choose to pin your images on the wall, you need to figure out the best way to do this. If the purpose of the show is to sell your work, then pinholes in your photos might not be desirable to potential buyers. Also, unframed prints don't look as professional or finished (the buyer can't just take home an unframed print and hang it on the wall).

How many images should you exhibit, and at what sizes?

Determining how much work to prepare and how big to print comes down to price and space. Your exhibition budget can only be determined by you – and how many pieces you can make, and the size at which you can get your work reproduced, is going to be determined by your budget.

It is also important to know how much space you have available for the exhibit. If the space has only 3 m (10 ft) of wall space, then putting up three images that are one meter (39 in) across will make it crowded and not allow enough space between each photo. However, if you have 10 m (33 ft) of space, and you put up four images that are only 50 cm (20 in) across, that will give you too much space between them.

Consider the space carefully. If you think your work looks great when enlarged, then perhaps having fewer, large pieces is better. But the larger they are, the more they will cost.

The same goes for the number of images. You don't want to completely fill the space – giving each image room will allow them to be shown better. Just because you paid for the space doesn't mean you have to fill it up. And if you choose to frame, consider the size of the frames, as well!

Editioning your photography

Editioning is also referred to as “limited editions” and is something to consider with photography. Printmakers have been doing this for centuries. It means that you're promising your potential clients that only a certain number of those images (prints) will be available for sale.

Editions can be a good way to make your work more valuable. If you have an image and do an edition of 20, then you need to make sure that the buyer knows what number in the edition they are receiving (8/20, for example). You need to keep records of this so you know how many prints of the image you've sold. Once you've sold 20, you can't sell anymore. You made a promise to those who bought the first 20 that you would only sell 20 of them. Think about how many prints of a photo you might sell from the start, and be realistic.

Another thing you need to be careful about with editioning is making sure the photos are all printed exactly the same. They all have to be consistent. If you put a piece in a show and sell it a few times, people won't be happy if the image they receive is not the same as the one they saw in the exhibition. You don't have to get them all printed at the same time, but make sure you use the same printer for all of them and that the printer knows how to replicate them identically.

Selecting a printing medium

The medium you choose for printing should be determined by your budget – but you should also consider how to make your work look its best. Do you want prints in frames? Or is canvas better for the type of image you'll be printing? Getting work printed on metal is becoming popular now as well, though it is also very expensive and (arguably) only suits some styles of photography.

Whatever you choose, you need to be careful. You want to show off your work in the best way possible . Consider printing some of your images a few different ways, then deciding which you like the best.

Choosing which images to exhibit

Choosing the images to include in the exhibit is the hardest part for most people. How do you know what images will be the best to show? There is no real way to tell.

If you are working with a gallery that employs a curator, you can likely get a lot of help from them; they can use their experience with the gallery and what sells to give you advice. If a curator isn't available, you might have to enlist the help of friends. Ask them to identify their favorite pieces. Perhaps your social media sites will also help you see the images that were most popular online.

When it comes to curating the show, there should be a cohesiveness to the work and to the final exhibition. Make sure all the work fits together and flows well. Be clear on your vision for the exhibition. The better your images look on the walls, the more you could sell.

Start planning your photography exhibition!

Hopefully, this article answered many of your questions about exhibiting photos, and explained some of the ways that galleries work.

There are a lot of decisions that need to be made, and before you start preparing, it is good to have a plan of what you want to do, why you want to do it, and how you will pay for it.
